title: Sundubu Jjigae (Soft Tofu Stew)
description: A warming Korean soft tofu stew simmered in a savory-spicy broth with silky uncurdled tofu, aromatic garlic and scallions, and optional seafood or pork. Brightened with toasted sesame oil and a splash of fish sauce or soy for depth, it finishes with an egg for richness.

ingredients.notes: use fresh soft/silken tofu in its tube or pouch; drain excess liquid
adds body and umami; omit for lighter broth

ingredients.display_name: shallot or small onion, thinly sliced
anchovy broth or dashi or low-sodium chicken broth
ingredients.notes: homemade anchovy-kelp stock preferred for authenticity
fish sauce for seafood depth, soy for vegetarian option

ingredients.display_name: small raw shrimp or clams or mussels (optional seafood)
ingredients.notes: shellfish should be fresh; omit for vegetarian

ingredients.display_name: thinly sliced pork belly or pork shoulder (optional)
ingredients.notes: use if making a meat variation

ingredients.display_name: scallions, thinly sliced (white and green parts separated)

ingredients.notes: crack into stew at finish for classic finish
about 1 cup cooked rice per person

steps.text: Prepare ingredients: mince garlic, thinly slice shallot/onion, slice zucchini and mushrooms if using, chop kimchi if using, and separate scallion whites and greens; drain soft tofu gently and set aside.
Heat oil in a small heavy-bottomed pot over medium heat, add scallion whites and shallot/onion and sauté until softened and fragrant, about one to two minutes.
Add minced garlic and cook until aromatic, then stir in gochugaru and optional gochujang and cook briefly to bloom the chili, about 30–45 seconds, stirring constantly so it does not burn.
Pour in the anchovy broth or chosen stock and bring to a gentle simmer, scraping any browned bits from the bottom of the pot.
Add soy sauce or fish sauce, sliced vegetables and kimchi if using; simmer until vegetables are tender, about 4–5 minutes.
Gently slide the whole block or spoonfuls of soft tofu into the simmering broth, nestling pieces without breaking them up too much; simmer gently for 2–3 minutes to heat through.
If using seafood or thin pork slices, add them now and simmer until just cooked through (shrimp/mussels or thin pork will cook in 2–3 minutes). Adjust seasoning with salt, soy or fish sauce to taste.
Crack an egg into the center of the stew and cover the pot; cook until the egg white is set but yolk remains runny, about 1–2 minutes, or longer to desired doneness.
Finish with a drizzle of sesame oil, scatter scallion greens and toasted sesame seeds, then serve hot immediately with steamed rice.
